key_insight: This (author-corrected) work demonstrates a scalable, error-robust DNA data-storage pipeline by combining coding-theory designs that respect biochemical constraints with deep-learning–based decoding to recover data from noisy reads.
problem_solved: Addresses the high error rates, biochemical constraints and limited scalability that have prevented practical, reliable DNA-based archival storage and retrieval.
method: Design constrained error-correcting codes tailored to DNA synthesis/sequencing constraints (e.g., GC content, homopolymers) to reduce systematic errors and enable scalable encoding.
Use deep learning models for read clustering, denoising and decoding to improve recovery of original data from noisy sequencing reads and to handle complex error patterns.
Integrate coding-theory and ML in an end-to-end pipeline that optimizes storage density, robustness and cost-efficiency for large-scale DNA archives.
impact: Makes DNA a more practical medium for long-term, high-density archival storage and shows how ML can enhance physical-layer decoding — relevant to AI/ML practitioners working on systems, data archival, and hybrid coding+learning solutions.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram showing: data → constrained encoder (coding theory) → DNA synthesis → sequencing reads → deep-learning decoder → recovered data
Bar chart comparing error rates / recovery accuracy with and without the deep-learning decoder
Icon-based schematic of biochemical constraints (GC balance, homopolymers) and how constrained codes avoid them
Scalability vs cost plot illustrating storage density and retrieval success as dataset size grows
paper_title: Author Correction: Scalable and robust DNA-based storage via coding theory and deep learning
paper_authors: Daniella Bar-Lev, Itai Orr, Omer Sabary, Tuvi Etzion, Eitan Yaakobi
